On 23rd November 2025, our group of thirteen travelling with "Flamingo Lanka Tours" embarked on a memorable visit to the historic Buddhist temple "Isurumuniya", gracefully perched on a rocky outcrop beside the tranquil waters of Tissa Wewa.  This ancient monastic complex, believed to have been established in the third century BCE by King Devanampiya Tissa, shortly after the arrival of Buddhism Sri Lanka, has been shaped and enriched by generations of subsequent rulers. Our exploration began at the temple‚Äôs archaeology museum, home to a remarkable collection of rock carvings.  The centrepiece, the bas-relief known as the "Isurumuniya Lovers", dating back to the fifth century CE, captivated me with its delicate depiction of a woman seated gracefully on a man‚Äôs lap ‚Äì a timeless symbol of artistry and emotion.  Surrounding this masterpiece were numerous other sculptures, each radiating an almost unbelievable beauty and craftsmanship.  I was immersed for over an hour, admiring these treasures and reflection on the stories they silently conveyed. After our time in the museum, we ascended the rock outcrop to visit the small stupa, enjoying sweeping views and a sense of tranquility that seemed to linger in the air.  The experience was both spiritually uplifting and artistically inspiring. A visit to ancient Anuradhapura would be incomplete without experiencing the wonders of Isurumuniya ‚Äì a place where history, spirituality and art converge in unforgettable harmony.

This is a beautiful historical site situated by the side of the "Tisa Wewa" and a fully-fledged Buddhist temple, where devotees can worship the essential features of a temple: the stupa, the Bodhi Tree, and the Image House. According to the chronicle, after receiving the tooth relic from India (309 AD), King "kithsirimevan" placed the relic here. The figure of a man and horse carved on the rock by the side of the image house was believed to be Agni as fire, and the man sitting in the royal posture as "Parjanya," the rain god. A pre-Buddhist cult worshipping the rain god may have continued throughout the Anuradhapura period because the sculpture is believed to have been created between the 5th and 7th centuries. "Isurumuniya" is famous mainly for its sculptures, of which the majority are non-religious and most probably bought from the adjoining "Ran Masu Uyana" (pleasure gardens for the Kings).

A temple that doesn't experience high volumes of tourists, this site is worth the visit. The on-site museum features numerous sculptures that originate from the temple. The most noteworthy are the 'lovers' and the 'kings family'. Beside the museum is a rock-cut shrine room featuring an extremely colorful reclining Buddha, a beautifully painted ceiling, and other images of Buddha. Adjacent to the pond is another shrine room featuring images of Buddha below a makara torana. Beside the pond itself and carved into the rock face is a sculpture known as 'the man and his horse', and two sets of carvings of elephants. Many people will miss this site while travelling in Anuradhapura, but I thoroughly enjoyed it and would definitely recommend others go.

Isurumuniya is one of the popular places visited by tourists.  The Isurumuniya temple was built by Devanampiyatissa (307 - 267 BC)during his rule of Anuradhapura.  He was son of King Mutasiva who ruled in 367-307BC, who built the Mahamevnawa Park and grandson of King Pandukabhaya founder of Anuradhapura kingdom ! According to historical facts, during Devanampiyatissa‚Äôs reign the Buddhist Monk(Thero) Mahinda(Mahendra) brought Buddhism to Sri Lanka. It stated 500 children of high-caste were ordained into Buddhism, and Isurumuniya was built for them to reside. Mahinda Thero lived here for a while. It also stated Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi Tree Sapling was brought by daughter of Emperor Ashoka, Theri Sangamitta, also sister of  Monk Mahindra(Mahinda).

We spent about 40 minutes having the history of the the Rock Temple explained to us and visiting the different areas. Of particular interest was the reclining Buddha and the history of his life. As with all the temples and stupors we found them to be extremely challenging in the hot sun, many areas were just too hot to walk on, you‚Äôve been warned. However, having said that we thoroughly enjoyed our visit and to get the best out of it you should engage a guide. Highly Recommended.

Excerpt from my Blog Post: Though the temple itself is not as grandiose or impressive as its counterparts, there was a quiet tranquillity to it which became apparent as soon as I began to approach the entrance... As I removed my shoes and payed the toll to enter, I was truly not ready for the sensory overload that lay ahead. Upon my entry I was overcome by the monotone prayers coming from the speakers at the front of the temple, the feel of warm dirt beneath my bare feet, and the smell of flowers which came with every breath of crisp air I took in.... I made my way to the side of the temple and began to climb upward. It was a short climb (as I would appreciate in the coming days), and just a few minutes later, I was looking down from the top of the temple over the pond and out to the lush land that surrounded the are for miles Though I did not find this to be an overwhelmingly spiritual or religious experience, I drew strength from knowing those on the ground, on the rock, and inside the temple were on a mission of days, months, years, and lifetimes to better understand themselves and their surroundings albeit in a purely spiritual sense.

When you set aside religion and look at these ancient sights as landmarks to this area and to the country.¬† As a tourist they are worth a visit as much as you would visit the Eiffel Tower in Paris and the Statue of Liberty in New York etc, etc. There is something to get from visiting them.¬† Something to feel and understand.¬† It is the feeling of the heat of the paved slabs or rock steps under your feet and an appreciation and understanding forming of what worship is like for these people here.¬† It is the physical exertion on your body to reach the highest point.¬† It is the tranquility of the landscape that these sights are built around.¬† It is the bewilderment of the age of the relics and the size in which some have been made.¬† It is the sights of monkeys behaving like this is their home.¬† It is the noise of traditional music as an organ may be playing if you were to visit a Cathedral.¬† It is the gentle murmurs of worship coming from peoples prayers.¬† It is the shade of the tree whether it be regarded as holy or not.¬† It is the smell of incense and the sight of flowers given as a gift.¬† It is the welcoming smiles of the Sri Lankan people who are happy to include you here regardless of your religion. It is something you do and recommend you do when you are visiting another country.

Isurumuniya temple has been constructed in Anuradhapura Kingdom era. It is situated nearby Tissa Wewa (tank). You can see a lot of mind blowing stone carvings there. There are the world famous Isurumuni Lovers, the Man and the Horse Head, Elephants pond, King's family and lot of other carvings (see the photos). If you love to read the ancient history of Sri Lanka, here is an ideal place. Remember to wear long and well covered dresses (or take a cloth to wrap around). Otherwise you will not be permitted to enter to the temple. I guess you can understand why, it is very sacred place.

The temple Isurumuniya is one of the places where lord buddha visited in Sri Lanka. Also, arahat Mihindu thero visited here. Therefore Buddhists (especially Sri Lankan) have a religious value here. The ancient cave temple was built in 3rd century BC and renovated several times during the Anuradhapura era. Important thing is, the carvings at the pond in this temple is unique to here. "Man and the horse", "Bathing elephants" are among them. According to legends, King Dutugemunu frequently visited here and spend time. The temple is situated 2 km away from the Anuradhapura new town. Plenty of parking space is available. Also you can walk to the "Ranmasu Uyana" (The ancient royal garden) and Tissa Wewa (the lake built by Kind Devanampiya Tissa) The temple has a small museum which the entrance is free. The famous rock carvings (Royal family, The couple) are there in the museum. All the artifacts were found nearby the temple. Therefore, the belief is, there was a garden for royals to spend time and the artifacts were situated in it. Since Isurumuniya is a Buddhist religious place, please wear appropriate cloths.

On tour of historical sites, this was our first stop. Entrance fee was 200 rupees and nominal tip to watch your shoes. Nice pond and rocks with carvings. Views from top of other stupas was nice. Most people seemed to miss the small building on the right as you exit with the Isurumuniya lovers carving.

Entry is 200 rupies per person. Great view from the very top of the rock. Museum with stone sculptures. Wall with paintings about the history of the place with explanations. Sacred place, dress bright and with long trousers! Nice lake next to it.
It needs entrance fee to enter this temple. But, as a tourists, we did not find much to see, though our driver said this temple was one of the oldest Buddhist temples. I would not recommend this.

We went to this Temple in the weekend. There were many locals which I liked. The pictures on tripadviser make it seem huge but it actually is (relatively) small. The museum is tiny and in my opinion not nessecary. There is a hal with some buddha statues. The ceiling of this shrine is beautifull. On the wall are ancient drawings which depict the creation of this shrine, these alone are worth the trip There is also a small batcave and the tiny rock gives you a nice view of the surrounding stupas. At the end of the parking lot are the Royal Pleasure Gardens which we very calm. We saw some monkeys and you can see old ponds that were once connected. The entrance fee was 200 roepies pp

Nice ancient temple with nice carvings. There is a museum which have many ancient ruins to get historical information about this place. There are booklets that can be bought to now much about the place. There is pond infront and the architecture is beautiful.

go there at early morning, not so big but ok. carving is nice & overall environment is peaceful & beautiful. but a bit difficult when i left at early morning. need to walk outside to the main street for catching tuktuk. maybe later will have more truck coming in. not so crowd but ok to take 30-1hr visit if you have time in anuradhapura.

local and foreign travellers must.visit one ofn important place in anuradhapura. small temple with good stone carving. can visit popular isrumuniya lovers carving.  top of rock amazing view & surrounding area better go early in the morning or evening time.
This is an ancient temple of Buddhist believers. Its a nice place to visit. It also has a small pond in the front.

We all (especially the kids) have a special love for this place. This place is not usually busy like the usual temples and ruins. Also have a peaceful surrounding where you can just sit back take in the views - ponds inside and around with lotus flowers, etc. There is also a nice view point at the top. Worth a visit and place you can just sit and chill also

We visited this sight first on our 4.5 hour tuk tuk sightseeing tour of the Ancient sites (we paid Rs 2500 for the tour but appears we paid way more than necessary as we booked this through our guesthouse - other drivers are only charging ~ Rs 1500, however we still felt this was value for money as our driver Fernando was very knowledgeable and a very pleasant). It cost Rs 200 per person to enter, as well as a tip to the man looking after our shoes upon leaving (we gave Rs 50 which he was happy with). We arrived at the site at about 8.30 and it was very peaceful. Our driver described the different aspects of the temple, the components of the moonstone and the balustrades. The views from the top of site are lovely. As you leave this site walk to the opposite side of the car park where there are new toilet blocks being built. There you will find a sign for the Royal Gardens. If you follow this path you will come to the lovely baths for the female royalty and then the male royalty. Just prior to these baths is a path that leads left up to a rock, at the back of this rock you will find the star gate carved into the rock face, thought to be related to those in Egypt and Peru.
We enjoyed this short stop on our busy day. The artefacts in the small museum date prƒô 3rd century BC. And you can get to the top of a small hill to take in the wonderful views
An interesting part of the whole complex. I found lots of interesting features and especially liked the carving of the elephant on a rock just above the tank.

According to my view this site is not a religious place. Actually this place got many things to see around... Awesome stone carvings / nice little rock which you can climb ( can have great view of huge lake) nice little pond & etc etc....if you visit Anuradhapura don't forget to be at Isurumuniya
Another rock temple we visited. This is also a nice temple with so much beautiful monuments. Stupa in the top of the rock has a wonderful view of the surrounding plain.
This place is magical. It¬¥s really old and the whole atmosphere was fantastic. The view is great and all the religious Buddha statues are breathtaking.

Enjoyed this Temple. The view from the top of the boulders is amazing, even with the air polution. Very serene place. 200 Rupee entry fee for access to the temple. The "foreigner shoerack" is just outside the entry gate.

We visited Anuradhapura on our second day in Sri Lanka and we were hapoy, that we met Mr.Kithsiri. We can not imagine better guide. His knowledge and presentation skills were amazing! He is guide with 35 years experience and he does his job with all his heart. The most attractive quality of Kithsiri is simple and clear¬†briefing¬†about the budism and Anuradhapura ancient city. He take you place to place and give you cream of history to get better idea of them. What you pay to ¬†Kithsiri you will never feel worthless. His contacts are donkithsirim@gmail.com Mobile phone: +94 71 642 13 79

You get to see world famous rock carvings Isurumuniya lovers (said to be prince Saliya and Asokamala ) and royal family carvings etc. These are said to be remains of a temple built by king Devanampiyatissa. When you climb up the rock the view is amazing. There's a museum next to the temple which is a must see.

This is a nice little temple with a few things to see: -lying Buddha and paintings on the wall -bats in the cave right after it -a nice Dagoba to see -and a nice little pond For the entrance, 200 Rupees per person, it's quite worth a visit.

Isurumuniya Temple was built 250  - 201 BC by King Devanmpiyatissa. It's a lovely place with interesting water feature where on the back wall are gorgeous carved elephants from the 7th century. The temple is good to see and not hard to climb. Allow a good half hour here while allowing one full day minimum to see all the sites of Anuradhapura. Wear easy off shoes to enter temples. Out of respect wear light colored clothing (preferably white) with knees and shoulders covered to enter temples.
The museum adjoining to the temple provides best rock carving in the world. The sharpness of the carvings is incredible. No other place in Sri Lanka provides such an incredible carvings.
There isn't a ton to see here. Just the old temple site, some carvings, a newer temple with some Buddha statues and an old tree. As with most places admission is cheap at something like 200 LKR.

We went here in the afternoon when there were a lot of local people dressed in white. This combined with a beautiful temple and great views from top of the temple left a sacred feeling. The temple and surrounding area are rather small - takes about 30 min - 1 hour to explore. Also it doesn't have many steps as several other temples have. Entrance fee 200Rs. per person. efinitely worth a visit.

Views are just amazing. I have no words to describe this place to make an honor to it. Lots of steps to walk to, but in the end is the price. Climbing to the highest rock was bit scary but the views! Three tumbs up to this! Entrance fee 500r was reasonable.
Its better to wear socks if you are going in the afternoon. Very hot and u cant wear shoes to walk around the temple.
We went there to visit the temple, and it was a nice visit with beautiful views, but the temple was a little far away and it was small compared with the others from the sacred area

I have been to here many times. For the first time we saw wishes rock. If there is a person to explain the things the gem will go to the world. You can buy a booklet in German language about Sri Lanka for your further exploration.
A buddhist temple in srilanka with climbing rock.We were there for 2 hours and went to see tissawewa the tank done by a famous king in Anuradhapura.
Remember to wear long trousers and woman to wear shirts the civil defence were strictly adhering to policy. But the temple was amazing, get there early to miss the crowds.

Must see place. The very first Buddhist temple in Sri Lanka. Greatly run and public toilets are the best around. When you climb the rocks you gets a beautiful 360 view of Anuradhapura. Also ask to be shown the 'gold fish' park, "Ranmasu Uyana"
Isurumuniya is a Buddhist temple situated near to the Tisawewa. There are four carvings of special interest in this Viharaya

The mix of ancient and modern budhism rest seamlessly side by side the local people obvervant of thousand years old traditions fascinating for foreigners too. Climb up to the stupa and look for Buddhas tooth transported from india to safety in Sri Lanka
Interesting temple. Nice elephant relief on side of pool, great views. Well worth a visit. Can be visited without the main site ticket. Just 200 rupees admission.
Sacred Buddhist temple. You will find the great carvings of "Isuruminiya pem yuala" (Isurumuniya Lovers), "Minissa saha ashwa hisa" (Man & Horse head), Elephant Pond Carving. Ample car park

Great sacred place for Buddhist. Nice temple. One of historic places in Sri Lanka. Wearing full clothes is advisable or else carry a shawl or similar robe. Being a temple short clothes are not permissible.

This was my first site in Anuradhapura and I would highly recommend others to start here.  My driver arranged a site guide who was excellent as he not only showed me around here, but other ancient ruins.  The history he told about Buddhism, the meanings behind the Dagoba, image house, the reclining Buddha, the historic Bodhi tree and the moonstones and guardstones brought life to the area and helped in understanding future areas I visited.  The view itself from the top by the Dagoba is worth the visit alone.  As it is a sacred place, advice is to dress respectably i.e. shoulders and knees covered (both genders).  Also you have to take your shoes off and the ground can become hot so it is wise to wear socks.  Take your time, sit in front of the Bodhi tree and chill.  Enjoy

This place is closest to railway station of Anuradhapura. Have 3 location that you can visit. The rock, Temple and Buddha sleeping In this area you need to removed your foot wear, they allow us to wear socks

A Dagoba with lovely and interesting carvings on the rocks. You can climb up stairs to the top and see a nice view of the surrounding area. The area borders a large tank which can be accessed via a path to the right of the temple complex.

This is quite a large complex, so you have to walk some distance without shoes. So don't go in the heat of the day. However, it is worth the hot feet. There is a lot to see here, and the climb to the top part gives you  a beautiful view.

Quite why one is charged $25 for a block admission ticket and we are then charged extra for various sites is not obvious.This site is interesting but nothing special and does not merit yet another fee
Great view on the surrounding area from the top of the rock. Entry fee 200 rupees. If you come during a hot noon better bring socks, as walking barefooted on hot stones might be unpleasant.

The temple has lots of historical value. Make sure that you visit the park just beside the temple. It has lots of things to see, especially the remains of a palace and other buildings. Once you finish just climb up the bank of the pond. If you go late in the evening you'll be able to experience a great sunset in peace. Very relaxing.
ancient temple with unusual rock carvings & a small museum includes the famous Isurumuniya lovers carving

A temple full of history & beautiful  stone carvings, a must visit. Get a Guide or Guide book if you are interested in the history of this place, in any case it is worthwhile looking around. Early morning till about 11am & evening after 4pm is the best time due to the heat. Be appropriately dressed as a mark of respect to Buddhism.

This is a Buddhist Temple and there is interesting story behind this place. There are four carvings of special interest in this Viharaya. They are the Isurumuniya Lovers, Elephant Pond and the Royal Family. You must come and get experience by .enjoying the visiting this place with its amazing story

Some great statues to be seen here. Rock carvings. As in all temples you need to take your shoes off, be sure to take some socks along. The surroundings can become very hot to walk on. It is not a big climbe to get there, easy acces.

This visit was long planned but due to having so much to see and do around the Polonnaruwa area, we got delayed. It was getting quite dark but we made a conscious effort to squeeze this one in, as our last port of call-of-the-day. And we were not disappointed. The area was quiet but well lit. We left our shoes by the entrance at the  police post. The sandy ground was cool and was less pebbly than in other areas. The climb up the steep stairwell up to the rock summit took some nerve: a small child and his parents had also left it until the last minute and the mum found a less direct route (on the left) to the top, which I recommend to those with no head for steep climbs. The Rock Temple itself, I missed, as I was transfixed by the 'Man and the Horse' carving to the right of the Temple. A man, whom I presumed was a fellow visitor warned us in no uncertain terms that this was 'not the time to be moving around'. It was too dark to see all of the majestic beauty that this temple and the museum had to offer anyway and I took his advice and left. I need to go there again for a proper look.
Before you 'take a picture of the famous lovers' sculpture, read the signs prohibiting photography and show a little respect.

An interesting site. The rock temple is an easy climb. Underneath there is a cave inhabited by a large number of bats. The sculpture of "The Lovers" in the museum is worth seeing. It helps to wear socks as walking up to the  site on the very hot stones and sand pathways can be very difficult in bare feet
One of my favourite places to visit in Anuradhapura! The giant buddha cave is filled with bats, the elephants carved into the rocks are beautiful.

As other reviewers have noted, shoes and hats must be removed before entering this Temple.  The distance from the entrance to the Temple is about 100 yards and the surface is dirt with small stones.  In addition, the climb to the top of the complex without shoes is a challenge.  Wear an extra pair of socks to help cushion the feet.  Picturesque view across the pond towards the Temple.  Entrance fee was Rs 200/person on March 1, 2016.
In the first capital city it's a modest temple built into the Rock. Said to be the first in Sri Lanka. An insight into Buddhism with the temple, image house, stupa and tree

Isurumuniya Rock Temple has no special features but it has less crowds compared to other Dagoba's in Anuradhapura. Sitting by the pool side and watching the locals feeding the fish was relaxing especially during the sun set.
There is lots of history in this place, including the famous sculpture of the Isurumuniya Lovers. Very peaceful place to spend some quality time

This was a cheap option. One can walk from town ( along, sweaty walk) and pay relatively small amount of money to see a substandard temple in the rock. If you are well traveled, don't need to come see this. You leave your shoes outside and pay for it. Then you walk either on your socks or barefoot and keep on jumping from one hot stone to the other. You go up on hot, rocky stairs to see NOTHING. The "museum" is substandard as well. Then you walk out to get your shoes back when you are asked to pay a TIP on top of the money you already paid to keep your shoes. This must be a real practical joke.

It was exiting to visit this little temple, as I had a photo of how it was in 1897 when my grandfather saw it and described it in his journal. There are several exquisite carvings, some carved out of the great Boulder, and others housed in the little museum next to the temple. Some are definately Buddhist, others look almost Hindu. The main Buddha in the temple is a little hard to see and impossible to photograph, as it is behind glass which reflects the light. As is the case with most of the temples, the steps are very steep. A wonderful view from the top of the temple.
Small but well worth to look at. The museum has the greatest stone cast Lovers‚Äù. Also the ancient stone casts. It is really worth to visit this temple, and walk through to the top of the rock.

My wife and I found this temple interesting. We were fortunate that we received good information whilst we were there from a gentleman who was also visitng with a relative from overseas. Betwen the two they gave us an insight that we may otherwise have missed. One thing though we must have very tender feet from years of wearing shoes and we found the relatively long distances walking without shoes a bit hard. We have walked many temples and this was one of the few places we found the stones hard going. Still glad we did it and would recommend it to others.
Some good features and an interesting site, both climbing up on top and the statues and paintings inside.

Adventure proud Sri Lions history tells us this wonderful world is still amazing designs before leaving this wonderful environment full of Sri Lankan heritage bequeathed a proud salute to the past must be given automatically to children respect for our King.

Isurumuniya is temple with lot of cultural and artistic values. Unlike other temples, Isurumuniya has lot of artistic rock carvings. This proves that King used this place to spend his leisure time. The famous rock carving of "Isurumuni Pem Yuwala" (Isurumuni lovers) is in exhibition at the museum. Don't forget to see the carvings of bathing tuckers near the pond and also the "man and the horse" image on the rock. These carvings are unique to Isurumuniya.
Nice little temple with a stupa.  Most of the carvings have been removed and transferred to the museum on site

I really liked this temple. You can see "the lovers" (stone carving) in the small museum. There are beautiful elephant carvings on the right side of the stairs, behind the lotus pont, on the left side of the rock.

Nice place with great views from the top. Is not as big and crowed as the other places in the zone. It is a good place to spends 30 to 45 minutes and take rest and have great vies from the top of the temple

200 Rupee only for this distinct temple. Amazing big rocks gate to pass under and very big rock to get on top. Easy to discover it was just near to the Anuradhpura heritage site. Lover stone was in small museum there too. Need a hidden cam to take picture. Otherwise ask permission may need some money to pay ?

This temple is a little out of the way from the main sites and therefore less frequented by locals and tourists. The lack of crowds gives this place a serene feel with it's small temple carved into the rocks and overlooking a pond. Picture perfect.

Anuradhpura seems to be beyond the standard tourist trail so there were really only Buddhist pilgims at this temple when we visited. Large reclining idol of Buddha in cave, great views of Anuradhpura from the top of the rock, and very loud bat colony also in the rock!

Review for a solo traveller. Travel tips to reach Anuradhpura: Colombo to Anuradhpura: Bus journey more than 200 plus km & 7 plus hours journey. Train option is also there. Train journey is more comfortable than bus. Kandy to Anuradhpura: Bus journey more than 150 km more than 6 plus hours journey Dambulla to Anuradhpura: Bus journey more than 70 km & more than 1 & half hour journey Polonnaruwa to Anuradhpura: Bus journey more than 100 km & more than 1 & half hour journey On reaching Anuradhpura one has to hire auto at negotiated price for sightseeing. Anything in the range of 1300 to 1800 LKR is the auto hire charges. Auto driver will ask you to pay him little more instead of buying entrance ticket assuring you managing with the ticket check points on the sightseeing route. Entrance ticket is 1800 of Anuradhapura sightseeing if you produce original passport otherwise more than 2500 LKR. You will be provided with a CD. It will take 4 hours to see complete sightseeing of beautiful ancient ruins in Anuradhapura. Isurumuniya Vihara will be 1 of the 10 spots of your Anuradhpura sightseeing tour. There is a cave, pond & small stoopa on a cliff. Entrance fee of LKR 200. Large idol of Buddha in a sleeping pose is in the cave alongwith other amazing sculptures. You are allowed to take photos of Buddha Idol & other sculptures. You are not allowed to take your own photo inside the cave. Sight of Buddha idol & other sculptures inside the cave is excellent. From the cliff top, one can see very beautiful scenery all around. On the back side of Isurumuniya temple there is a big serene lake at a 5 minutes walk. You have to come out, take left turn reach the corner of temple compound, again take left turn, walk for more than 50 metres, climb up the inclined steps & you are in front of a big lake. See the attached photos.
A place to visit! It‚Äôs a beautiful and colorful temple with a wonderful garden and unique stone carvings. If you climb the rock, you have an amazing view of Anuradhapura. I loved being here.
Very beutiful temple. It was raining so we didnt get that true hype but anyway it was astonishing. Must go.

column7: Capelle aan den IJssel, The Netherlands
column11: Do not visit this temple in the weekend, because a lot of locals are going there. The temple is worthwhile to see inside, but you need a good guide who can explain the meaning of the interior of the temple
Best stone carvings you can see in this part of the world. However, the building requires an urgent repair, because water leaking during heavy rains.

This is not the most impressive of sites in the Anuradhapura area but one of the 8 sacred sites. The walk over stone steps and across sand-pebble stone areas is made easier when reading up on the history of the place beforehand. If available, bring along coins to dedicate to the deity by throwing it in the pond for good luck.

It was one of the excursions we did when we visited Anuradhapura with our family. Everyone should come and visit this Temple. There is a lovely museum inside the temple. Stunning views when you reach the tom of the rock. I would recommend this site to anyone. Make sure you wear appropriately (cover your shoulders and knees. Remove your shoes before entering the temple). I would suggest to put your socks on when climbing the rock. It is very hot during day time.

This temple is supposed to be first of them built in the ancient city. It is not covered under the tour package of Anuradhapura (the tickets can be bought from visitor's centre, 50% discount for SAARC countries). One has to pay extra to enter the temple and keep their shoes outside. It was too hot to walk barefoot so carry socks! this site can be skipped if tight on schedule!

If you are visiting Anuradhapura this will be in your itinerary. This shows the artistic expression of ancient kings of Ceylon. Isurumuniya is a statue of a lovers couple carved somewhere in 6 AD. Surrounding area is very beautiful and breathtaking. There is a small rock to climb which will give you an aerial view of the surroundings. As I said if you are interested in historical places don't miss it.

A nice temple to visit.Lot of stone carvings worth to see. The most famous one is Isurumuniya lovers.It is housed separately from the shrine room. You can climb the rock. There is a stairway behind. Nice view of Tissa wewa from the top of the rock. Nice breeze too and a good place to watch the sunset over the lake.
A nice to place to visit There are four unique carvings in the rock temple they are the Isurumuniya Lovers, Elephant Pond and the Royal Family. all carving are very unique
This place is just like a set from Indiana Jones. The carvings in the solid rock are incredible and the water garden surround is beautiful. One of my favourite visits during our stay.

A nice place to visit. The carvings housed separately, are very beautiful, as are the carvings on the rock (outside by the pond). Separate entrance tickets. Spacious car park. Almost next to Ran Masu Uyana.
Sparse remains of a once grand place of worship.  Neatly kept with no commercialisation nearby.  Steep entrance fee.

This is Buddhist temple now. But there is a version saying that this is place is built by King Ravana for his Parents. King  Wesamuni and Queen Kailasha. There is stone carving of lovers. And face of a man and a horse. That is King Wesamuni and his horse.
Big reclining buddha inside a cave with swifts and bats flying around you; places to climb and view and other rooms to see. Spent a happy hour there with the family

While it is unimpressive from the outside, once you enter, there is so much to see. This rock temple has some very fine carvings. Also in one of the caves is a serious of impressively colorful Buddhas, including a giant reclining Buddha, which was my favorite. It makes a tremendous photo!
An interesting story of forbidden love in a fine natural setting. After seeing many stones and temples the last days this one did not add to much value
This is one of the beautiful place in anuradhapura ! you can get the whole view of anuradhapura from top of the rock :)
This is a very quiet temple to visit in Anuradhapura with interesting sculptures. Extra fee is charged to visit it, I think it was worth it. Many locals come to worship here.
nice place for my 2 yr kid. he was enjoying the people around and running all around. it was so soothing wind. but we could not climb up with the kid in hot rock
Good rock carvings. Located next to Thisawewa Tank. Very nice location to relax. Can cover the location in 20-30 mins.
I began my journey around Anuradhapura here. Very pretty rock temple with pond. Close to one of the large tanks built in ancient times by King Devanampiyatissa. Well worth a visit.
sri lanka oldest and fist monastry temple. in anuradapura.small stupa on the rock, old and new palace  2 rooms.,small pond allso you can see

Ancient rock Buddhist temple with a water pond.Situated over the Thissawewa,which is an old tank build by the king Devanampiyatissa who was a friend of Ashoka emperor of India.World famous Isurumuni lovers, sculpture can be seen there.

If you like to enjoy this beautiful place and not to burn your foot (unless you are used to walking on hot coals), go there early in the morning or late afternoon or take the socks with you. As you know, in Buddhist temple you are not allowed to wear the schoes BUT nobody (so far) cares if you wear socks.
Very nice and pitoresque place with many enjoyable details. You can walk to the beautiful lake behind or continue to Vessagirriya rocks (not that much worth) and Mango Mango for dinner.

Even though this seems to be a part of Anuradhapura complex, this place requires separate tickets (Rs 200) and shows the statues. The statues seemed rather unimpressive to me, until I noticed the dates when they were created. They are really old! The piece that is considered to be the most significant item of the collection is The Lovers, but I can't really say it's much better than the other pieces. Consider this place a room of the British Museum or a such.

Isurumuniya is a little away from the Anuradhapura Stupas and very different too. You can see the Shrine, the Dagoba and the Bodhi tree in the temple. Once you climb up to the rock on which the Dagoba is situated, you can have a good view of the surroundings as well. There is a big pond and a museum as well within the temple area. The Museum has some of the old stone statues and carvings. Of this the statue of Isurumuni lovers is quite famous. This is very similar to the statues seen on most of the old temples in India. There is an entry fee of LKR 200.

It is something you should watch...isurumuniya lovers...is a carving done on rock...it is done in a way that depicts the youthfulness of yhe man and woman...the head of the man is slightly bent (its known as Nihanchita Mudra)signifies his love for the woman...right hand (Maura Mudra)signifies his pride about the woman...the woman shows slightly bent head too(Anchitha Mudra)and her right hand depicts Thirpathak Mudra denotes how willing she is to show her love...this rock carved sculpture is found in isurumuniya andit belongs to 4-5 century B.C.

Nice to get away from the busier and larger temples. This was perfect for me. Nice Buddha figures of various sizes inside the temple, a nice view from the rock and a pretty stone staircase. Found a chipmunk that enjoyed posing for the camera and a cave FULL of bats. Luckily, they're vegetarians, not vampires. Recommend bringing socks, the sand is VERY hot! Price is very cheap, about 200 rupees for the entrance, and some rupees to the man who guards the shoe. A monk was giving blessings inside the temple. All in all, a very nice experience!
It is a small temple, but it is different view and why not take few stairs and see the view.  :) I also saw bats!
This is a lovely peaceful beautiful place. Socks are essential to save your feet from the hot ground. When I was there there were small crowds, unlike the bigger sites

A nice change of pace for those looking to see a smaller but more tranquil stupa. You can climb to the top and get a nice view of the surrounding area. There is a nice pond, well kept grounds, and its much quieter than the bigger places in town. As with all other temples you need to take your shoes off, so be careful if you visit this place in the middle of the day. The hot sand can burn your feet!
This is on the outskirts of Anuradhapura. The eatery serves only non-veg food, so not helpful for vegetarians. This place is worth visiting for its calmness.

Compared to the gigantic stupas of Anuradhapura this temple is small yet we recommend visiting it for its tranquillity and interesting interior. It is noted for its wonderful carvings which indeed are worth viewing. Because it is not on the main tourist ticket of the cultural centre, it is quieter than other places and is in a very picturesque location. We are very pleased we visited it.

One of the very important monument of the Sri Lankan early kingdoms and buddhism history! More than 2200 years history! Don't forget, hat and shoes forbidden inside the sacred area. You will need sun protection cream, and exchange socks is very practical. The reason not just the dirty floor (these places wasn't really dirty), very often the stone very hot without shoes. I recommend you, before the visit you must read some historical fact about this place, will be interesting the visit!
There is not much to see here. You can only go for a walk behind the temple where there is a lake. Not a place worth visiting if you are in Anuradhapura just for a day.

This site is not on the main Anuradhapura ticket but is well worth a visit. The small temple is quite beautiful and there are some interesting carvings in the gallery. This site seems to attract less visitors than the other ancient monuments, rendering the visit more tranquil.
Nothing spectacular, but nice little rock temple. Good for a visit of 20 minutes on the way to somewhere else.

It's hard to believe that this fascinating place has been around since ~200 BC. The rock carvings are intricate and quite sublime. I liked the elephants by the square pool as much as those carvings which have been moved indoors and displayed more formally in the gallery. This temple is probably my favourite in Anuradhapura. Enjoy it. Don't forget to take a few coins to test your throwing skills at the square pool.

This is a very photogenic and tranquil spot and once housed the tooth relic.  There are also some beautiful carvings to see and whilst the site is quite small, it was quiet when we visited and very pleasurable to wander around.

The temple was built by King Devanampiyatissa (250 - 210 BC) and this mountainous site of Mihintale was filled with ruins, stupas, temples dedicated to the glory of historic encounter between Tissa and Mahinda.  The temple was located between two boulders with one adjoining a pond.  On top of the rock, you could have nice views on the surrounding.  The reclining buddha was the landmark in the Rock Temple. Worth visiting this spot when in Anuradhapura.

I went there  together with other norwegian citizen. Since they had Sri-lankan origin they went in for free when I was asked by a silly soldier women to pay tourist ticket because I was white. Because of  this experience I have desided not wisit Sri-Lanka anymore and I will not recomend that destination to anyone. What makes me realy pissed off is that Norwegian tax payers have helped that country billins of dollars but as we use to say in Norway ungreatfullnes is the worlds payment.

A beautiful small temple with ancient carvings constructed by Sinhala king Devanampiya Tissa. (307 BC to 267 BC) His reign was notable for the arrival of Buddhism in Sri Lanka under the aegis of Mauryan Emperor Ashoka who well known as Dharmashoka. The temple created using a rock.This is famous among travellers for it's lovely stone sculptures and the famous one is "Isurumuniya lovers". When you climb up the rock you can see a nice view of surrounding. This is located in a lovely location near Tissa tank in Anuradhapura. You can visit to Ranmasu uyana  next to the temple which is a lovely ancient park with rocks and ancient ponds. Charge for a foreigner Rs.300/=. Locals free of charge. It is better if you can wear white decent clothes covering your body since this is a Buddhist temple. Car park is available. According to my view this place is a must see attraction by a tourist.

It is here, by the side of the old relic house, that you can see the iconic rock carving of the man and his horse. The place is a quiet haven with a small but well curated museum, a reclining buddha in a cave temple, an old bodhi tree and a sacred rock to climb. In all, it has everything in a small area and  is not much visited so it's quiet. The downside is that it's not included in the Sacred City ticket so it will cost another 300 rp (for foreigners) but I think, unlike the Sacred City, it is value for money.

While this temple was pretty, I felt it didn't live up to the hype. I would place this temple much below Mihintale, the main dagobas, Bo Tree, twin ponds, moonstone etc. The temple needs better sign boards / explanatory boards. We did not have a guide, and did not really understand the significance of some of the components. We later got an excellent guide - Asoka - who showed us the main Anuradhapura ruins. I would recommend him very highly. His number is +94 718907081.
This temple needs to be on your must see list when in Anuradhapura. It can easily be reached through rural roads on a bike
Well worth a trip to see this place. Very peaceful and so very few tourists. The pool and rock carving were beautiful asking with the large reclining Buddha.

steps are very easy to go up, the guide boys are excellent. tfree they explained every this correctly. but monkeys are dangerous. they trying to stealing foods in hands. nice view on the top of the Mihintale.

An interesting complex to wander and climb up to the top, we visited just before closing at 6pm, but they let us wander without pressure to hurry, the museum part was closed by this time however. I think it remains open to pilgrims after this time as a large bus load arrived just as we were leaving, which was also fascinating to see such devotion.
It's a wonderful place to watch when you travel around Anuradhapura. If you know the local history it is more interesting.
A great way to experience Sri Lankan history from a Buddhist/cultural perspective. The main attraction here is a stone carving dating more than 1,500 years

This is quiet and charming with a nice museum next door. Photography is forbidden inside. Climb the temple, come down and perambulate under the old bodhi tree. Next to the temple pond are rock cutouts of an elephant and naag.

I learned that this is one of the oldest temple in Sri Lanka which is now one of the great attraction in Anuradhapura. Nice view around and walking on the top of temples is just great. There is nice museum which clarifies the history behind it. Tourist needs to buy a separate ticket here but if you are foreigner, living on residential visa, do not need to buy any ticket.

Felt this is the best attraction in Anuradhapura. Need to take another set of tickets to see this temple. The tickets purchased for 3250 bucks is not valid here. Paid around 500 bucks per person to visit this temple. Too steep for such a lame attraction! As usual, it has a Buddha statue. There is a water body next to it along with rocks. There is a formation in the rock where people try to throuw coins. It takes good aim to throw the coin directly into that slot. There is a cave next to it. It was filled with bats. We didn't go inside as it was dark and would be dangerous. Avoud going in the caves in the evenings. It can get very dangerous.

This is actually not a temple at its inception. That's one of entertaining site of an old king and later has become a sacred place once it rediscovered in recent eras. You must visit this place since once visited, it will excite you to re visit. The statue of Isurumini Lovers is the central attraction of this place. behind the temple, you can see the higher dam of Thisa wewa, one of largest man made tank. I have been there for more than 10 times.

After Budhism was Introduced to Srilanka by arahanth(Enlighten one)Mahinda in 3rd Century BC this temple was built by the king Devanampiyathissa who was ruling the country that period. It is a master pieace of great architecture within a rock.Temple comprises Srine room,Stupa and pond.Later The world famous Isurumuniya Lovers stone carving has being introduced by the kings during the 6-7 Century AD.This is a must visit place if you ever happen to be in ancient capital of Sri Lanka,Anuradhapura.

i have visited 3 times isurumuniya rock temple, feel so good in the mind when ever visit the temple, it has many stone carvings, special the carvings of true lovers, lovely view 360 degrees  when we are up in the rock, peaceful environment,
excellent location and proud to be a Sri Lankan. This was an ancient temple of Sri Lanka which was built by great Kings of Sri Lanka

There is a small temple within a rock and it is an easy climb up steps to get to the top of the rock and admire the views of the countryside. Judging by the number of Sri Lankans visiting here and the number of cars and buses it is a very important place for them. The area is very well maintained and there are interesting artifacts in the small museum obviously removed from their original locations to preserve them. It is also a pleasant walk to the area wheter there is a large glowing white stupa.

This is a temple with a difference. It was interesting watching people toss coins into the tiny enclave on the face of the temple - and mainly missing their mark as the coins hit the surrounding moat. Climbing the ancient rock adjoining the temple and viewing the forest environs from the summit was great, but I was very disappointed that the historic 'isurumuni lovers' has been removed from their original setting at the temple and are now homed in the adjacent museum. So many artifacts seem to be removed and put under protection this way. I suppose the authorities would say they had little choice in the matter, given the vandalism that takes place these days..
Visit the small museum close this monument , before to visit the city of anurhadapura .... and clim to the top of the rock you'll get a wonderful view !

Isurumuniya though not famous for it's stupa, was a famous temple historically for praying to the rain gods. Minimal effort to climb to the top of the rock. Excellent view of the surrounding area from the top of the rock. Make sure you visit the Museum and take some pictures of the famous lovers, a 6th Century Gupta style rock carving. The figures may represent Dutugemunu's son Saliya and the law caste (Sadol Kula) maiden Asokamala whom he loved. It's known that he gave up the throne for her. the tour can be completed within half an hour.

I like it for the fact that it's breezy on the top though a little (very minimal) climb (stairs) is needed and you will have a great view, overseeing Tissa Wewa. One of my favourite temples in Sri Lanka, and one that leaves a deep impression. It is near to the Sri Maha Bodhi temple. Worth a visit if you are nearby. The entrance fee (Rs.200) is not included in the rest of the ancient sites, so do it on a separate day. We didnt have guide to tell us stories, nor we are historical buffs who want to write a journal about it, but we enjoyed the view and serenity.

Take your socks as this is a hat and shoe free zone.  Socks are acceptable and respectful.   Fascinated watching the local attendees throwing coins into the rock opening, and then the climb to the top of the rock well worth the crowd and wait.
It a must see in Anuradhapura. Ancient feeling, nice statues and story. Our guide was very well informed and willing to share what he knows about the temple. Entrance fee is 200LKR.
Another must see sight in Anuradhapura. This place is world famous for its sculpture of the "Isurumiya Romantic Couple". There're some other stone carvings outside the temple, just above the pond.

A beautiful temple you should absolutely visit whilst exploring the sites of Anuradhapura. The site is really beautiful and it's lovely to wander around. The small museum on site is interesting. It costs 200 rupees to enter. This is one of the places you should absolutely make time to visit.
We went there with our family. First ever in my life I witnessed a bat cave. One of the must see historical place in Sri Lanka.

Famous for `Isurumuniya Lovers' and the temple was built by King Dewanampiyatissa. Has a very rich history of the place and carries a lot of historical values for the Sri Lankans. A place must visit if you visit Anuradhapura.

Not what you would expect. Right now they are "restoring" it but its like a do-it-yourself version and takes away from the fact that this is a world heritage site. It would have been better if they left it as it was.

A compact place.  You get to see beautiful sculpture of a sensual couple (you can see it on postcards).  The climb up the dagoba was rewarded with a good view of the surrounding.  A reclining budhha.in one of the rooms.  Good option to spend if you have extra hours in Anuradhapura. http://clumsycompass.blogspot.sg/2013/03/blog-entries-on-sri-lanka.html

It is little away from main attractions but its the first temple in sri lanka. Museum inside is pathetic...5 rocks with carvings.. cave with bats is nice ans noicy..climb the top  to engoy the view and breez. Entrance is 200 but it seems if to approach construction from left side there is no wall or fence.. funny..

what was known as meghagiri vihara/issarasamana vihara,earlier,  now commonly known as isurumuniya vihara or isurumuniya.it was a temple of 32 dcaves.soon after the buddhishm was introduced in 3rd bc many including royal & wealthy entered the buddhist order.so king devanampiyatissa made arragementsin this temple for the occupation.this is also the place where the sacred tooth relic was originaly kept n exposition held n belonged to abhayagiri monastry.but to day this great temple has become world famous for the timeless masterpiece of stone carvings. at the enterd to the rock temple is a large pond.above the pond there is a carving of bathing eliphants n  on the top level of the stair there isanother carvings of the man seated in royal pose n a horse head.this carving is thought to b of agni n parjanya.parjanya is the god for rain.The elephants below represents the clouds.with this interpretation  late prof.paranawithana says that this has been a place of worship of rain god parjanya.Some other granite slabswith carvings which have been brought from the royal plessure garden close by,r kept by the museum.the most popuaer being  that of the LOVERS .it is vastly believed to b of prince saliya(the son of great king dutugamunu)

It may not take long to visit, but this is a nice attraction to visit. It has a good sense of intimacy after some of the larger and busier sights.  We took a tuk from town and back which was not far.  One of the nicest spots in Anuradhapura and no selling going on. Great in the late afternoon.

We almost missed this temple as it is slightly away from the other sites. But we're glad we went. The temple is small but very charismatic. The reclining buddha is beautifully painted as is the room where it is housed. There is also a bat colony, a very busy squiggly bunch but fun to watch.

It is a beautiful complex and it is one of a few places in Anurathapura, where we can see beautiful stone carving (the lovers and horse man, king and consort) rather than the remaining cement, bricks and gigantic stupa.  Entrance fee is very cheap comparing to the 25 USD price to see the big dagoba where you can see from the road side.
Once again the ancient architecture is amazing.The carvings done on stone is so precise that one is amazed by the talents of the stone sculptures.
This is supposed to be the oldest rock temple in Sri Lanka.  It is quite interesting and a good place to visit.
... if you hear loud noises, raise your eyes. It could be a huge population of bats living in this temple.
nothing special to see, lovers sculpture, dagoba,ponds, but the cabe full of bats did impress me, on my 3rd day sri lanka, not knowing, that bats often hang in trees. entrance fee 1100 rps

Isurumuniya rock temple is a beautiful peice of artifact  as well as a relegious temple located in the secred city of Anuradhapura. The twin ponds , the cool breeze flowing from one side over the Thissa wawa , water tank and the temple itself which had been built on a rocky surface are fine constructional achievements made by the ancient kings. The world famous stone carving of "lovers" called the lovers of Isurumuniya has been preserved and a historic story backs it. It is a unique construction with most of the carvings and the temple done purely with granite stone.

This is a nice location and very well kept, again a hot foot massage. The guide was very limited with his vocabulary of English and we had to fill in the blanks he would create. Being an Indian we were aware of the story of Buddha so it was easier to comprehend what he was trying to say.
Also lovely place to visit. In anuradhapura you cant walk in day time as it was very hot.the structure is amazing.
An example of a small Sri Lankan temple in the rock. Charming place. A lot of bats in the rock uder Dagoba on the top.
This site reminded me of the world heritage sites in Capadoccia Turkey. Paintings were better preserved here.

Another one of the amazing places in Anuradhapura. The carvings inside the museum are really beautiful. A place where a prince had to hide because of his affair with a low caste lass. Truly worth a visit.

The temple complex was interesting as a cave monastery and reliquary.  The dying Buddha statue was massive. Not far away we also saw the rock from which Buddha is said to have launched himself on his flight back to india. We also saw the "Stargate" diagram.  Google this for Info.

It is a nice temple built as a fusion with a rock, where you can see carved the famous 'horse and man' and the well preserved carved elephants bathing in the small lake. Near to it you can get ot know more about the history of the Isurumunya Lovers.

Legends has it that the first relic of the Buddha was put here in the days of the emperor Ashoka, and the atmosphere makes one willing to believe this record from the Chronicles. It was a monastery then, it still is.

I saved $25 admission fee, 100% of airfare and lodging and snacked from my own kitchen... all by using the internet. I think I traveled to Myanmar, Burma that same day. Very cool places to see. No TSA No Customs No Passport No government hassles. Where do you want to go?

As with all things holy in Sri Lanka, you remove your feet and walk around barefoot.  The grounds themselves are in decent shape, but I'm sorry to say, and I"m going to come across as an arrogant sounding tourist here, but:  having to skip around from shady spot to shady spot and wincing every time my feet felt jagged stones was not a pleasant experience, and far from a spiritual one.  Be prepared to have your feet burned off. The temple itself is nothing spectacular.  There is a old bath with some carvings, and stairs to climb up a boulder.  There's another grotto kind of built into a cave with Buddha statues.  Interesting, if you don't mind the hundreds of bats that have made it its home - although you can get some photos there.  Once you see all three things, each worth about 5-10 minutes of your time, you're pretty much done...  I honestly found the surrounding lily ponds and view of the reservoir more interesting than the temple itself.  Definitely see that. All in all, a somewhat mediocre site as far as historical/cultural attractions go.  I pegged down because of 1) the shoe policy: temples elsewhere, for example, often hand out clean flip flops to use.  and 2) The site itself was simply not that spectacular.  I mentioned this in another review of Anuradhapura, but skip this town unless you have time.  Sigiriya and Polonaruwa, in the cultural triangle, are both more interesting.
it just amazing work done by an ancient sri lankan...

I was there quite early and there was no entrance fee. You can climb the rocks, visit the temple inside and see some swallows and bats that made the temple their own. The whole visit takes only 15 minutes, you need to take off your shoes.
For westerners unused to walking barefoot outside, this is rather hard going but worth it none the less. The little museum has interesting carvings and the view from the top is worth the climb.

The temple is located away from the archaeological center and would take a bus ride to get there. Personally I did not find the temple itself too impressive but if you are in Anuradhapura for over 2 days and are done seeing the historic center then visit the temple for its carvings.

I visited Isurumuniya with my family mates, for the "n"th time, and I still can't stop admiring this historical site. Being a local I must state, that visiting these sort of historical sites require no special local guide, as the directions are given appropriately and besides the local community offers genuine help when you need the most. Remember to take off your shoes and hats/ caps while you're visiting the place, obeying the religion and its values. I would also recommend travelers to avoid shorts/ sleeveless materials at the time of visit.

This was an excellent beginning to my visit to Anuradhapura's many sights. Guides are available and I strongly advise to think  carefully about this. Hiring a guide is helping them to earn a living of course, but at some places it is not really necessary. The choice is yours.

This place is famous for the carving of a couple said to be the brother of king Dutugemunu . Saliya and his bride Asokamala whom he loved. It's known that he gave up the throne for her. The rock sculpture is in side the museum for safety. and from out side you can climb to the top of the rock and see the surrounding area.

A temple that doesn't experience high volumes of tourists, this site is worth the visit. The on-site museum features numerous sculptures that originate from the temple. The most noteworthy are the 'lovers' and the 'kings family'. Beside the museum is a rock-cut shrine room featuring an extremely colourful reclining Buddha, a beautifully painted ceiling, and other images of Buddha. Adjacent to the pond is another shrine room featuring images of Buddha below a makara torana. Beside the pond itself and carved into the rockface is a sculpture known as 'the man and his horse', and two sets of carvings of elephants. Many people will miss this site, but I throughly enjoyed it and would recommend others go.
